frame.name: Adjacency
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Figure</fen> is located adjacent to a <fen>Ground</fen>. This is equivalent to the <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> either constituting or being associated with a zone, with each zone in contact with the zone of the other.
<ex><fex name="Figures">The two houses</fex> were <t>adjacent</t> , so she bought them together .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">The bedroom</fex> <t>adjoining</t> <fex name="Ground">hers</fex> was much smaller .</ex> <ex><fex name="Figure">The park</fex> <t>borders</t> <fex name="Ground">a very upscale neighborhood</fex> .</ex> <ex>While you solder , make sure the <t>neighboring</t> <fex name="Figure">pins</fex> don't get overheated . <fex name="Ground">DNI</fex> </ex>
This frame is intended to cover productive metaphor cases such as those found in "adjacent web pages"--referring to pages that metaphorically "share a border" by virtue of sharing a hyperlink, as well as many additional cases of entities which are cognitively associated in other ways. There are a number of less productive metaphors that are also intended to be included in this frame, e.g. "behavior bordering on lunacy", "cleanliness is next to godliness", despite the fact that conventionally we do not find "adjacent to lunacy", etc. Though these expressions sound creative, they are immediately understandable and contextually unobjectionable.</def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
<ex>The cat is <t>adjacent</t> <fex name="Grnd">to the mat</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
<ex><fex name="Fig">The cat</fex> is <t>adjacent</t> to the mat.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Distance
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Distance</fen> between the <fen>Figure</fen> and the <fen>Ground</fen>. This FE requires an image schema with a vector that extends from the <fen>Ground</fen>, or a subpart of the <fen>Ground</fen>, in some direction, and the <fen>Distance</fen> is measured along this vector from the <fen>Ground</fen> to the profiled region.
<ex>The cat is <fex name="Dist">immediately</fex> <t>adjacent</t> to the mat.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Direction</fen> from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the <fen>Figure</fen>. This FE is filled by one of a closed class of adverbs: up, down, out (meaning 'beyond the boundary around the viewpoint'), off (meaning 'disconnect between landmark and figure'), back (meaning 'along a line from front to back of landmark, and relatively inaccessible'), and, more rarely, away, along, and dialectally, back down (meaning 'down and behind'). </def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
</def-root>

FE.name: Figures
FE.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Figures</fen> are items which mutually serve to identify the location of the other items.</def-root>

FE.name: Deixis
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how the locative phrase relates to the grounding of the speech situation, either locating it near (here) or far (there, yonder), or specifically separated from the speech context by distance or a barrier (over). Fillers of this FE are restricted to this closed class of items.
<ex>It is lying <fex name="Deixis">here</fex> <t>next to</t> my desk.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Accessibility
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how accessible the <fen>Figure</fen> is to some participant in the speech context (either the speaker or the addressee, or some other highly salient viewpoint in a narrative). This FE normally describes availability for manipulation and use, but may simply describe how easily seen or difficult to see the <fen>Figure</fen> is. There is a closed class of items that can fill this slot, including only 'just' and 'right' indicating ease of access, and 'way', 'all the way', or (dialectally) 'clear' indicating distance and difficulty of access.
<ex>The flashlight 's <fex name="Accessibility">right</fex> <t>next to</t> my handbag.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Directness
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how closely the position of <fen>Figure</fen> matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target. This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, directly, and due (and some combinations of these), but also occurs with rarer items like 'smack dab'.
<ex>The houses are <fex name="Directness">directly</fex> <t>adjacent</t> to each other.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: adjacent.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: in an area immediately next to an area occupied by (something).

lexUnit.name: neighbor.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to be in an area next to.

lexUnit.name: adjacency.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the state of being in zones bordering each other.

lexUnit.name: contiguous.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: (esp. of a group of zones) sharing common borders (without occupying the same space).

lexUnit.name: contiguity.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the state of sharing a boundary with.

lexUnit.name: neighbor.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: an entity that is next to (some contextually relevant entity).

lexUnit.name: abut.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (of land or a building) be next to or have a common boundary with
